Address: 3343 Maplewood Rd., Victoria, B.C.
Birthplace: Rochester, Kent, England

1. What year did you start homesteading in Eastern Canada? 1928.
   Where did you see it homesteading? Atwood and Anneslie, N.S.
   What hard work may you have had before that? Carrying water, chopping wood, etc.
   For how many people did you live? 7.
   How far was it to your nearest store? 1 mile.
   How often could a visit be made to the store? Twice a week.
   What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years?

To: Mrs. A. Smith
From: Mrs. John Kemsley
Date: [illegible]

2. Flour and other grain products
   What brand of white flour did you use in the early years?
   Hungryman Patent Gold Star.
   In what quantities did you buy it? One hundred pounds.
   Was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour $4.25?
   How much did you use grated flour?
   Whole wheat flour?
   Was flour milled locally? Yes.
   How far away? 1 mile.
   What was the price for a twenty pound bag of flour? 60 cents.
   What other grain products did you use?
   Cornmeal?
   Other?

Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? Yes.
For did you grind it? With a hand mill.

19. Have you ever returned to almost starvation level living on or near the local prairie? Give details.

We have known what hardship on the prairie meant.

In 1904 my family lived away from the prairie.

In 1905 we moved back to the prairie.

In 1906 we moved again.

In 1907 we moved back to the prairie.

In 1908 we moved again.

In 1909 we moved back to the prairie.

In 1910 we moved again.

20. What do you think was the greatest hardship?

The greatest hardship was the lack of food.

21. How did you manage to get through those difficult winters?

We managed to get through those difficult winters by working hard and saving money.

22. Did you ever experience any major disasters?

Yes, we experienced a major disaster when our house burned down.

23. How did you manage to rebuild after such a disaster?

We managed to rebuild after such a disaster by selling our possessions and starting over.

24. What do you think was the greatest achievement?

The greatest achievement was surviving the harsh prairie conditions.

25. How did you manage to survive in such difficult conditions?

We managed to survive in such difficult conditions by working hard and relying on each other.

26. What do you think was the greatest lesson learned?

The greatest lesson learned was the importance of hard work and perseverance.

27. How did you manage to overcome any obstacles?

We managed to overcome any obstacles by working together and never giving up.

28. What do you think was the greatest challenge faced?

The greatest challenge faced was the lack of resources and the harsh prairie conditions.

29. How did you manage to adapt to the new environment?

We managed to adapt to the new environment by learning new skills and adapting to the new surroundings.

30. What do you think was the greatest surprise?

The greatest surprise was the beauty of the prairie and the resilience of the people who lived there.

31. How did you manage to adjust to the new lifestyle?

We managed to adjust to the new lifestyle by learning new skills and adapting to the new surroundings.

32. What do you think was the greatest impact on your life?

The greatest impact on our lives was the opportunity to experience the beauty of the prairie and the resilience of the people who lived there.

33. How did you manage to maintain your faith during difficult times?

We managed to maintain our faith during difficult times by relying on each other and seeking comfort in our beliefs.
